ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies that PROC SUMMARY displays the descriptive statistics.
Specifies that PROC SUMMARY does not display the descriptive statistics.

[Syntax: ALPHA=α] 
      
Specifies the confidence level to compute the confidence limits for the mean. The percentage 
for the confidence limits is (1 - α)×100. For example, ALPHA=.05 results in a 95% confidence 
limit.

Specifies that the _TYPE_ variable in the output data set is a character representation 
of the binary value of _TYPE_.

[Syntax: CLASSDATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies a data set that contains the combinations of values of the class variables 
that must be present in the output.

Creates all possible combinations of class variables even if the combination does not 
occur in the input data set.

[Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set<(data-set-option(s))>] 
      
Identifies the input SAS data set.
Orders observations in the output data set by descending _TYPE_ value.
Excludes observations with nonpositive weight values (zero or negative) from the analysis.

Excludes from the analysis all combinations of the class variables that are not found in the 
CLASSDATA= data set.

[Syntax: FW=field-width] 
      
Specifies the field width to display the statistics in printed or displayed output.
Specifies that the output data set contain the minimum value of the ID variables.

[Syntax: MAXDEC=number] 
      
Specifies the maximum number of decimal places to display the statistics in the printed 
or displayed output.
Considers missing values as valid values to create the combinations of class variables.

Suppresses the column that displays the total number of observations for each unique 
combination of the values of the class variables.
Enables parallel processing of the input data set.
Disables parallel processing of the input data set.
Disables floating point exception (FPE) recovery during data processing.

Specifies that the output data set contain only statistics for the observations with the 
highest _TYPE_ and _WAY_ values.

Specifies the sort order to create the unique combinations for the values of the class 
variables in the output.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Orders values according to their order in the input data set.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Orders values by their ascending formatted values. This order depends on your operating environment.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Orders values by descending frequency count so that levels with the most observations are listed first.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Orders values by their unformatted values, which yields the same order as PROC SORT. This order  depends on your operating environment.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies the mathematical definition that PROC SUMMARY uses to calculate quantiles 
when QMETHOD=OS.       To use QMETHOD=P2, you must use QNTLDEF=5.

Displays all requested combinations of class variables (all _TYPE_ values) in the printed 
or displayed output.
Displays the values of the ID variables in printed or displayed output.

[Syntax: QMARKERS=number] 
      
Specifies the default number of markers to use for the P² quantile estimation method.
Specifies the method that PROC SUMMARY uses to process the input data when it computes quantiles.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Uses order statistics. This method is the same method that PROC UNIVARIATE uses.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Uses the P² method to approximate the quantile.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the amount of memory that is available for data summarization when you use class variables.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the amount of memory in multiples of 1 (bytes). Replace n with an integer value.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the amount of memory in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes). Replace n with an integer value.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the amount of memory in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes). Replace n with an integer value.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the amount of memory in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). Replace n with an integer value.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the maximum amount of memory available.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the divisor to use in the calculation of the variance and standard deviation.
Sum of squares corrected for the mean
Percent coefficient of variation
Measures heaviness of tails.
One-sided confidence limit below the mean
Maximum value
Arithmetic mean
Minimum value
Most frequent value
Number of observations that are not missing
Number of observations that are missing
Range calculated as the difference between maximum value and minimum value.
Measures the tendency of the deviations to be larger in one direction than in the other.
[STDDEV] Standard deviation
Standard error of the mean
Sum
Sum of the weights
One-sided confidence limit above the mean
Uncorrected sum of squares
Variance
Middle value
1st percentile
5th percentile
10th percentile
Lower quartile (25th percentile)
Upper quartile (75th percentile)
90th percentile
95th percentile
99th percentile
Interquartile range and is calculated as Q3-Q1
Two-tailed p-value for Student's t statistic
Student's t statistic

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BY <DESCENDING> variable-1 <...<DESCENDING> variable-n> <NOTSORTED>;
      
Produces separate statistics for each BY group.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately 
follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.
Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ID variable(s); 
      
Includes additional variables in the output data set.

Syntax: CLASS variable(s) </ options>;
      
Specifies the variables whose values define the subgroup combinations for the analysis.

Required Arguments:

variable(s) 
specifies one or more variables that the procedure uses to group the data. Variables 
in a CLASS statement are referred to as class variables. Class variables are numeric 
or character. Class variables can have continuous values, but they typically have a 
few discrete values that define levels of the variable. You do not have to sort the 
data by class variables.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies to sort the class variable levels in ascending order.
Specifies to sort the class variable levels in descending order.

Excludes from the analysis all combinations of the class variables that are not found in 
the preloaded range of user-defined formats.

Specifies not to apply formats to the class variables when PROC SUMMARY groups the values to 
create combinations of class variables.
Considers missing values as valid values for the class variable levels.

Enables PROC SUMMARY to use the primary and secondary format labels for a given range or 
overlapping ranges to create subgroup combinations when a multilabel format is assigned 
to a class variable.
Specifies the sort order to create the unique combinations for the values of the class variables in the output.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Orders values according to their order in the input data set.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Orders values by their ascending formatted values. This order depends on your operating environment.  If no format has been assigned to a class variable, then the default format, BEST12.,  is used.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Orders values by descending frequency count so that levels with the most observations are listed first.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Orders values by their unformatted values, which yields the same order as PROC SORT. This order  depends on your operating environment. This sort sequence is particularly useful  for displaying dates chronologically.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies that all formats are preloaded for the class variables.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: FREQ variable;
      
Specifies a numeric variable that contains the frequency of each observation. 
 
Required Arguments:

variable 
specifies a numeric variable whose value represents the frequency of the observation. 
If you use the FREQ statement, then the procedure assumes that each observation represents 
n observations, where n is the value of variable. If n is not an integer, then SAS truncates 
it. If n is less than 1 or is missing, then the procedure does not use that observation to 
calculate statistics.

The sum of the frequency variable represents the total number of observations.

Note:   The FREQ variable does not affect how PROC SUMMARY identifies multiple extremes 
when you use the IDGROUP syntax in the OUTPUT statement.

Syntax: WAYS list;
      
Specifies the number of ways to make unique combinations of class variables. 
 
Required Arguments:

list 
specifies one or more integers that define the number of class variables to combine 
to form all the unique combinations of class variables. For example, you can specify 
2 for all possible pairs and 3 for all possible triples. The list can be specified 
in the following ways: 

    m

    m1 m2 ... mn

    m1,m2,...,mn 

    m TO n <BY increment> 

    m1,m2, TO m3 <BY increment>, m4
 
Range: 0 to maximum number of class variables

Syntax: OUTPUT <OUT=SAS-data-set> <output-statistic-specification(s)> 
      <id-group-specification(s)> <maximum-id-specification(s)> 
      <minimum-id-specification(s)> </ option(s)>; 

Writes statistics to a new SAS data set. 

output-statistic-specification(s)
  specifies the statistics to store in the OUT= data set and names one or more
  variables that contain the statistics. The form of the output-statistic-specification is
  
      statistic-keyword<(variable-list)>=<name(s)>
      
  where
    statistic-keyword
      specifies which statistic to store in the output data set.
    
    variable-list
      specifies the names of one or more numeric analysis variables whose statistics you
      want to store in the output data set.
      
    name(s)
      specifies one or more names for the variables in output data set that will contain
      the analysis variable statistics. The first name contains the statistic for the first
      analysis variable; the second name contains the statistic for the second analysis
      variable; and so on.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
          
Names the new output data set. If SAS-data-set does not exist, then PROC SUMMARY 
creates it. If you omit OUT=, then the data set is named DATAn, where n is the 
smallest integer that makes the name unique.

[Syntax: IDGROUP(<MIN|MAX (variable-list-1) <...MIN|MAX (variable-list-n)>> 
<<MISSING> <OBS> <LAST>> OUT <[n]> (id-variable-list)=<name(s)>)

Combines the features and extends the ID statement, the IDMIN option in the PROC 
statement, and the MAXID and MINID options in the OUTPUT statement to create an 
OUT= data set that identifies multiple extreme values.

[Syntax: MAXID<(variable-1 <(id-variable-list-1)> <...variable-n <(id-variable-list-n)>>)> = name(s)
            
Specifies that one or more identification variables be associated with the maximum 
values of the analysis variables.

[Syntax: MINID<(variable-1 <(id-variable-list-1)> <...variable-n <(id-variable-list-n)>>)> = name(s)

Specifies that one or more identification variables be associated with the minimum 
values of the analysis variables.

Specifies that PROC SUMMARY appends the statistic name to the end of the variable label. 
If an analysis variable has no label, then PROC SUMMARY creates a label by appending the 
statistic name to the analysis variable name.

Specifies that PROC SUMMARY creates a unique variable name for an output statistic 
when you do not assign the variable name in the OUTPUT statement. This action is 
accomplished by appending the statistic-keyword to the end of the input variable 
name from which the statistic was derived. For example, the statement 

      output min(x)=/autoname;
      
produces the x_Min variable in the output data set.

Specifies that statistics in the output data set inherit the length of the analysis 
variable that PROC SUMMARY uses to derive them.

Includes a variable named _LEVEL_ in the output data set. This variable contains a value 
from 1 to n that indicates a unique combination of the values of class variables (the 
values of _TYPE_ variable).

Specifies that the variables in the output data set that contain statistics do not inherit 
the attributes (label and format) of the analysis variables which are used to derive them.

Includes a variable named _WAY_ in the output data set. This variable contains a value from 
1 to the maximum number of class variables that indicates how many class variables PROC SUMMARY 
combines to create the TYPE value.

[Syntax: CSS<(variable-list)>=<name(s)>]
          
Sum of squares corrected for the mean

[Syntax: LCLM<(variable-list)>=<name(s)>] 
          
One-sided confidence limit below the mean

[Syntax: N<(variable-list)>=<name(s)>] 
          
Number of observations that are not missing

[Syntax: NMISS<(variable-list)>=<name(s)>] 
          
Number of observations that are missing

[Syntax: RANGE<(variable-list)>=<name(s)>] 
          
Range calculated as the difference between maximum value and minimum value.

[Syntax: SKEWNESS|SKEW<(variable-list)>=<name(s)>] 
          
Measures the tendency of the deviations to be larger in one direction than in the other.

[Syntax: STDERR<(variable-list)>=<name(s)>] 
          
Standard error of the mean

[Syntax: UCLM<(variable-list)>=<name(s)>] 
          
One-sided confidence limit above the mean

[Syntax: QRANGE<(variable-list)>=<name(s)>] 
          
Interquartile range and is calculated as Q3-Q1

[Syntax: PROBT|PRT<(variable-list)>=<name(s)>] 
          
Two-tailed p-value for Student's t statistic

[Syntax: CSS=<name(s)>]
          
Sum of squares corrected for the mean

[Syntax: LCLM=<name(s)>] 
          
One-sided confidence limit below the mean

[Syntax: N=<name(s)>] 
          
Number of observations that are not missing

[Syntax: NMISS=<name(s)>] 
          
Number of observations that are missing

[Syntax: RANGE=<name(s)>] 
          
Range calculated as the difference between maximum value and minimum value.

[Syntax: SKEWNESS|SKEW=<name(s)>] 
          
Measures the tendency of the deviations to be larger in one direction than in the other.

[Syntax: STDERR=<name(s)>] 
          
Standard error of the mean

[Syntax: UCLM=<name(s)>] 
          
One-sided confidence limit above the mean

[Syntax: QRANGE=<name(s)>] 
          
Interquartile range and is calculated as Q3-Q1

[Syntax: PROBT|PRT=<name(s)>] 
          
Two-tailed p-value for Student's t statistic

StatementHelp.#cdata:
VAR variable(s) </ WEIGHT=weight-variable>;
    
Identifies the analysis variables and their order in the results. 

Default: If you omit the VAR statement, then PROC SUMMARY produces a simple count 
of observations, whereas PROC MEANS tries to analyze all the numeric variables that 
are not listed in the other statements.  

Interaction: If you specify statistics on the PROC SUMMARY statement and the VAR 
statement is omitted, then PROC SUMMARY stops processing and an error message is 
written to the SAS log.  

Required Arguments:

variable(s) 
identifies the analysis variables and specifies their order in the results.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: WEIGHT=weight-variable
        
Specifies a numeric variable whose values weight the values of the variables that are specified in the VAR statement.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: WEIGHT variable; 
      
Specifies weights for observations in the statistical calculations. 

Required Arguments:

variable 
specifies a numeric variable whose values weight the values of the analysis variables. The  
values of the variable do not have to be integers. If the value of the weight variable is 

  o Weight value... PROC SUMMARY... 
  o 0 counts the observation in the total number of observations 
  o less than 0 converts the value to zero and counts the observation in the total number of observations 
  o missing excludes the observation 

To exclude observations that contain negative and zero weights from the analysis, 
use EXCLNPWGT. Note that most SAS/STAT procedures, such as PROC GLM, exclude negative 
and zero weights by default. 

Restriction: To compute weighted quantiles, use QMETHOD=OS in the PROC statement. 
Restriction: Skewness and kurtosis are not available with the WEIGHT statement. 
Restriction: PROC SUMMARY will not compute MODE when a weight variable is active. Instead, 
try using The UNIVARIATE Procedure when MODE needs to be computed and a weight variable 
is active.
